data.title: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError thrown sometimes when returning to idle desktop game window
data.body:
hi,
actually I'm not sure if it's a libgdx issue or a kotlin issue (since the game core is implemented in kotlin) but I **occasionally** get the mentioned error when I trigger any ingame ClickListener of a non-focused desktop window.

data.title: Scene2D - Stage calling Batch.begin() & Batch.end() on an instance it doesn't own.
WebGL banding on smooth alpha gradients
data.body:
I've got a LibGDX game with cartoon clouds with a smooth gradient. There are other examples of gradients in the game that have a similar issue, but the clouds are the most obvious example. They look fine in Android, on iOS and on the Desktop version of the game, but on the WebGL version the gradients are not drawn as smooth. It only appears to be alpha gradients that have the problem. Other gradients look ok.

I've used a custom shader to pin down the cause of the banding, and the banding occurs in the colour channels, not in the alpha, but only occurs on textures with an alpha gradient. I'm wondering if it's some kind of precision issue with alpha premultiplication, as the alpha channel itself isn't effected. But if that's the case I don't understand why it's only occurring in WebGL and why the brightness cycles from light to dark across the bands rather than just being a flat colour in the bands. If it was a precision issue within the texture in VRAM then that also wouldn't explain why the problem disappears when using `GL20.GL_SRC_ALPHA, GL20.GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_ALPHA` as the blend function when still using the premultiplied png.

I've tried on 3 different devices in Chrome and IE, and all 3 produce the same results. You can find a test of the HTML5 version here.

https://wordbuzzhtml5.appspot.com/canvas/

I've added an example IntelliJ project on github here

https://github.com/WillCalderwood/CloudTest

The critical code is `render()` [here](https://github.com/WillCalderwood/CloudTest/blob/master/core/src/com/mygdx/game/MyGdxGame.java)

The bottom image here is the desktop version, the top is the WebGL version, both running on the same hardware.

![enter image description here](http://i.stack.imgur.com/ui8rC.png)

There's nothing clever going on with the drawing. It's just a call to

```
    spriteBatch.draw(texture, getLeft(), getBottom(), getWidth(), getHeight());
```

I'm using the default shader, textures packed with premultiplied alpha with the blend function set as

```
    spriteBatch.setBlendFunction(GL20.GL_ONE, GL20.GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_ALPHA);
```

This is the actual image, although alpha not premultiplied as that's done by my packer.

![enter image description here](http://i.stack.imgur.com/Bk1s9.png)

Does anyone know a possible reason for this and how I might resolve it?

This only appears to happen when using the blending mode `GL20.GL_ONE, GL20.GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_ALPHA`

I've tried changing the whole game to use non-premultiplied alpha textures. I use Texture Packer which can help fix the halo issues that often occur with non-premultiplied alpha. All this works fine in the Android and Desktop version. In the WebGL version, while I get smooth gradients, I get still get a small halo effect, so I can't use this as a solution either.

Here's an image. Desktop version on the top, web version on the bottom. Blending mode `GL20.GL_ONE, GL20.GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_ALPHA` on the left and `GL20.GL_SRC_ALPHA, GL20.GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_ALPHA` on the right

[![enter image description here](http://i.stack.imgur.com/vrPQx.png)](http://i.stack.imgur.com/vrPQx.png)

Here's a zoomed version of the bottom left image above with increased contrast to show the issue.

[![enter image description here](http://i.stack.imgur.com/gv3si.png)](http://i.stack.imgur.com/gv3si.png)

data.title: Json Serialization of an instance's fields that are initialized during declartion returns {}
Fixed GWT by adding TiledMapTileMapObject.
data.body:
The title says it all. Fixes https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/issues/3313

Sorry about that. I keep assuming that all libgdx classes would be added automatically there for some unknown reason.

data.title: TexturePacker: added [settingsFileName] argument
data.body:
I'm working on a 2d game and found that the TexturePacker class has a very handy method which allows you to specify default settings in addition to the per-directory settings.

Unfortunately this argument is not supported via CLI so I had to create a wrapper class for my current project but felt like TexturePacker should support it by default as the method is already present.

data.title: Get orientation as Vector2 on Box2D Transform
data.body: Helps one avoiding have to sin and cos the returned angle from getRotation.

data.title: Request: LerpAngle on MathUtils.
data.body:
I would write a PR for this, since I found myself needing it more than once this week, but can't guarantee the solution I found to the problem is performant enough.

For more info, [this](http://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Mathf.LerpAngle.html) is what I'm requesting.

And [this](http://stackoverflow.com/a/14498790/1091440) is the best way that I found to do it . Anyone know a better way of doing it?

data.title: AudioDevice sampling rate
data.body:
The documentation for [AudioDevice](http://libgdx.badlogicgames.com/nightlies/docs/api/com/badlogic/gdx/audio/AudioDevice.html) says the device is 44.1khz (as does the source!), but a call to [newAudioDevice](http://libgdx.badlogicgames.com/nightlies/docs/api/com/badlogic/gdx/Audio.html#newAudioDevice-int-boolean-) allows the user to specify the sampling rate.

Should an implementation of the AudioDevice use a sampling rate provided by the user or ignore and default to 44.1khz? (I would hope you you will allow configuration, as I'm at least one person writing an application that requires the use of audio in different sampling rates.)

Also, I can see that at least the Android implementation does take the specified sampling rate into account when initializing a new AudioTrack, but I think the docs should reflect this if it holds over all platforms.

data.body:
How can enable multitouch on windows 8.1?
Thanks.

data.title: Update versions, also testing PR build, sorry for spam
Added TiledMapTileMapObject
data.body:
TilEd is able to have animated tiles and create objects from those. The current implementation in libgdx can only handle single texture regions via `TextureMapObject` though.

This PR adds a new kind of `MapObject` in the `tiled` package. The `TmxMapLoader` will now create `TiledMapTileMapObjects` instead of `TextureMapObjects`. These reference either a `StaticTiledMapTile` or an `AnimatedTiledMapTile`.

For compatibility reasons, it also `extends TextureMapObject` and should work exactly the same.

_This is the very first PR that adds this. There hasn't been any PR like this before._

data.title: Fix #3147 (with MathUtils)
data.body: New PR with MathUtils.

data.title: Fix #3299
data.body: With this, #3296 passes.

data.title: Intersector.splitTriangle reports wrong sides when splitting
data.body:
This bug has been found while creating #3296. When splitTriangle is given a triangle to split which needs to be split, it splits it correctly, but triangles which should be in the front are reported to be in the back and vice versa. This does not happen when the triangle is not split. Tested only with 2 vertices in the back and one in the front, I don't know if it works with reversed triangle.

![Image](https://i.imgur.com/USqrcuu.png)

This image shows what is being tested in #3296. The red triangle is first test - no splitting. Correctly reported as being in the back. Green triangle (with blue part) is the second test. It is apparent that there should be one triangle in the front and two in the back. All vertices are correct though.

data.title: Added TiledMapTileMapObject
data.body:
TilEd is able to have animated tiles and create objects from those. The current implementation in libgdx can only handle single texture regions via `TextureMapObject` though.

This PR adds a new kind of `MapObject` in the `tiled` package. The `TmxMapLoader` will now create `TiledMapTileMapObjects` instead of `TextureMapObjects`. These reference either a `StaticTiledMapTile` or an `AnimatedTiledMapTile`.

For compatibility reasons, it also `extends TextureMapObject` and should work exactly the same.

data.title: Fix Circle.contains
data.body: `contains(Circle)` would claim that a bigger circle can be contained by a smaller circle, which is wrong. Fixes an assert in IntersectorTest from #3296.

data.title: Create Intersector unit test from Intersector main
data.body: This creates an junit test in the style of `BitsTest` in `gdx/test`. Note that this test currently fails at line 28 (test_circle) due to bug in Circle.contains. Fix is in the followup PR. `intersectorTest` is currently not done yet, because I didn't have the time/tools/smarts yet to compute what should be the correct answer. So it wasn't included as a test yet.

data.title: Make GridPoint classes implement Serializable and provide toString()
data.body:
This was more of just a really simple quick fix so that:
- Serialization libraries don't choke on GridPoints since they previously did not implement `Serializable`
- The coordinates of a GridPoint can easily be accessed for debugging purposes with a simple `toString()`

And of course, the Vector class already has both of these anyways.

data.title: BaseTmxMapLoader loads TextureMapObjects incorrectly
data.body:
Hi I'm not sure what update it was in but I recently updated libgdx and noticed that my map objects were being loaded incorrectly.

 It used to load texture objects from tiled as RectangleMapObjects which was fine because i made a work around. Now it loads them as TextureMapObjects which is great!.... except it sets the texture incorrectly... I'm pretty sure this is a bug in the new update of Libgdx in the BaseTmxMapLoader class. 

PS: im not sure if this is the right place to post this but I just noticed it so I thought I would put this here. Feel free to move it if you need.
